page.title: 16PARK PLACE ESTATE
page.content: CONWAY'S BRIDGE. In 1752,General Conway called in Thomas Gainsborough,the Congregational Minister at Henley,as Engineer for a Bridge over HAPPY VALLEY.He transported large stones from Reading Abbey.It was known then as Ragged Arches.Today,it is Conway's Bridge in the Wargrave Road. Twenty years ago,some of the woodland was cleared in the Happy Valley & it is now a private Golf Course. The Area marked "WORKS" on the map is the site of a tunnel used in the Second World War for storing aircraft parts - Spitfires. "WOODLANDS" on the map is where Conway built a large Still House with coke ovens & he planted 20 acres of lavender The heads were distilled & the oil was sold.The Lavender Plantation was unique in the country.There are 200 acres of wood now.The land reaches Crazies Hill.
